thread.title: New segments, pit-road clock play role in Daytona 500
thread.title_full: New segments, pit-road clock play role in Daytona 500

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: New segments, pit-road clock play role in Daytona 500
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email New segments, pit-road clock play role in Daytona 500 Several former winners were knocked out early Sunday, but there were no yellow flag over the final 43 laps of the Daytona 500. Post to Facebook New segments, pit-road clock play role in Daytona 500 Several former winners were knocked out early Sunday, but there were no yellow flag over the final 43 laps of the Daytona 500. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2lKnM58 Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs New segments, pit-road clock play role in Daytona 500 A.J. Perez , USA TODAY Sports 8:38 p.m. ET Feb. 26, 2017 CLOSE x Share A quick look back at Kurt Busch's first win at the iconic race. USA TODAY Sports Ty Dillon (13) and Matt Kenseth (20) were part of a multicar wreck near the end of the second stage. (Photo: John David Mercer, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — There were crashes at Sunday’s Daytona 500, hardly a shocker since the season-opening race marked the debut of a new-three stage award system. 
And this was Daytona International Speedway, a restrictor-plate race where cars are bunched up and collisions are frequent. Drivers interviewed, usually after they climbed out of their mangled cars, said the addition of the segments — worth up to 11 points each — were a factor in the eight cautions as 15 cars were forced from the field. 
“It’s got everybody a little more amped up, but there are not a whole lot of cars finishing,” said Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series rookie Ty Dillon, who was consumed in a crash on Lap 142. “ It’s just part of racing here at Daytona. That is why it is one of the toughest races to win.” 
MORE DAYTONA 500: Dale Earnhardt Jr. crashes out of NASCAR return at Daytona 500 
Former winners Dale Earnhardt Jr., Jimmie Johnson, Matt Kenseth and Jamie McMurray were among the drivers forced out Sunday. 
There were no yellow flags, however, over the final 43 laps, making it the first time in at least a decade there wasn’t at least one caution within the final 12 laps of a finish. 
“We had a lot of young drivers up front, which was neat to see,” NASCAR Executive Vice President and Chief Racing Development Officer Steve O’Donnell said.. “You saw they could hold their own with a lot of aggressive driving as well. It was certainly surprising at the end to see that many green flag laps.” 
PHOTOS: Best of the 2017 Daytona 500 
The lack of cautions, something crew chiefs have come to rely on here, turned it into a gas mileage race as Chase Elliott, Kyle Larson and Paul Menard — all contending for the lead late — ran out of fuel, allowing Kurt Busch to win his first Daytona 500 in 17 attempts. 
The five-minute clock for pit-road repairs and the ban on cars returning to the track after a trip to the garage to fix race damage also made its debut. Busch, whose No. 41 Stewart-Haas Racing Ford, was part of a 17-car crash at Lap 129 just made it back out on the track before the countdown expired. 
“It’s going to be work in progress as we go (with) NASCAR working with the race teams,” O’Donnell said. “If it goes beyond five minutes, their day is over anyway. If we had a line of teams here saying we have to do something, maybe we’d do something. We didn’t have one of them. “
